title-group.article-title: Toxic effects of 50 Hz electromagnetic field on memory consolidation in male and female mice

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Psychology, Young Researchers Club, Naein Branch, Islamic Azad University, Iran
2Department of Electrical Engineering, Young Researchers Club, Naein Branch, Islamic Azad University, Iran
3Department of Psychology, Young Researchers Club, Bandargaz Branch, Islamic Azad University, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Elham Foroozandeh, Department of Psychology, Young Researchers Club, Naein Branch, Islamic Azad University, Naein, Iran. Email: Elham_for@yahoo.com

abstract.p: In this study, the effect of exposure to an 8 mT, 50 Hz extremely low-frequency electromagnetic field (ELF EMF) on memory consolidation of adult male and female mice was studied. For this purpose male and female mice were randomly distributed among six groups (n = 10 in each group). Using passive avoidance task, despite its natural tendency, mouse learns to stay on a small platform to avoidant electric shock. Immediately after the learning session, laboratory animals in the experimental groups were placed in an 8 mT, 50 Hz sinusoidal EMF for 4 h. The second male and female groups were sham exposed (exposure device off) and the third groups were considered as the controls. Twenty-four hours after the learning session, the animals were placed on small platform again and step-down latency was measured as the memory consolidation index. Significant (p < 0.05) decreases were determined among groups in memory function and results showed that exposure to an 8 mT, 50 Hz EMF for 4 h has devastating effects on memory consolidation in male and female mice.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In cognitive functions, ‘memory consolidation’ is a widely known phenomenon, and it refers to substantially vulnerable and disruption new memories but progressively strengthening over time (Dudai, 1996, 2004; Mc Gaugh, 2000). During this progressive post-acquisition stabilization of memory, protein synthesis is required (Dudai, 1996), but nowadays there are worries about the influences of electromagnetic fields (EMFs) on the cellular organisms, metabolism, biological processes and molecular mechanisms such as protein synthesis.

Whertteimer and Leeper reported the probable devastating effects of exposure to electric and magnetic fields in 1979 for the first time, which was related to electrical fields and cancer in children (Manikonda et al., 2007). In 1980, researchers found an increased risk of leukemia and brain tumors in people who were exposed to extremely low-frequency EMFs (ELF EMFs). Such finding led to increased attention to the risk of EMF (Ahlbom, 2001) and the risk of central nervous system disorders including Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s diseases in people who were exposed to occupational EMFs and electric shock (Ahlbom et al., 2004).

EMF showed damaging effects on cognition and nervous system in animals using an assortment of behavioral tasks, tests and exposure conditions (Salzinger, 1994). Animal models and human designs have shown that ELF EMF can change the activities of peripheral and central nervous system. Some of these changes eventually influence the learning and memory functions (Trimmel and Schweiger, 1998). These changes include the increased activity of hypothalamic nuclei and intracerebral nuclei (Sieron et al., 2001), neurotransmitter synthesis in synapses and ganglia (Massot et al., 2000), tissue damage on hypothalamus and pituitary gland (Dundar et al., 2009), changes in the activity of neuronal receptors including dopamine receptor and 5-HT (1B) (Chance et al., 1995), decreased amplitude value and hyperpolarization time of action potential in the sciatic nerve (Coşkun et al., 2011), increased intracellular Ca2+ levels, concomitant with increased activities of Ca2+-dependent protein kinase C, cyclic adenosine monophosphate-dependent protein kinase and calcineurin as well as decreased activity of Ca2+-calmodulin–dependent protein kinase in hippocampal regions (Manikonda et al., 2007).

Human cognitive functions and behaviors of animals can be influenced by exposure to ELF, which has been shown by behavioral and psychological studies (Fu et al., 2008; Lai, 1996; Lai and Carino, 1999; Lai et al., 1998). For example, rats exposed to 25 or 50 Hz fields in the short term (7 days) or long term (25 days) were examined in the Y form maze. The findings showed that neither short-term- nor long-term exposure did not make a change in motor activity, but 50 Hz field exposure will decrease recognition of new arm of the maze (Fu et al., 2008). Jadidi et al. (2007) approved that 20 min exposure to 8 mT, 50 Hz field can impair spatial memory but such impairments cannot be created by a 2 mT field.

On the other hand, some researchers have reported that ELF fields have no effect or probably positive effects on cognitive functions. Aldinucci et al. (2009) stated that after 2-h exposure to a 2 mT ELF O2 consumption ATP production remained intact in synaptosomes, intrasynaptosomal Ca2+ concentration enhanced slowly, no depolarization of the synaptosomal membrane was detected and the release of free iron and F2-isoprostanes by synaptosomal suspensions also remained unchanged. These findings showed that weak pulsed EMFs have no significant influence on the physiological behavior of cortical synaptosomes. Regarding the positive effects, Liu et al. (2008) examined spatial learning and memory changes using Morris water maze after 4 weeks of exposure to ELF EMF (4 h daily with a 50 Hz, 2 mT ELF). They reported that such exposure leads to reduced long-term delay in finding the hidden platform and improved long-term memory, without an effect on short-term memory or motor activity. Kavaliers et al. (1996) have observed behavioral improvement in mice water maze responses that is associated with biological opioid system.

Considering the above findings, it is not correctly confirmed whether the ELF fields can improve memory or impair it as a cognitive function. This study investigated the effect of ELF EMF (50 Hz) on memory consolidation in adult male and female mice.

sec.title: Subjects and experimental groups
sec.p: Adult male and female mice (25–30 g) were separately housed five per cage in a room with natural light cycle and constant temperature (24 ± 2°C). Food and water were available ad libitum. All procedures were conducted in agreement with the National Institutes of Health Guide for care and use of laboratory animals. Mice were divided into 6 groups (n = 30 male, n = 30 female and n = 10 in each group): 4-h exposure to 8 mT EMF, sham-exposed and control groups.

sec.title: Behavioral training
sec.p: This study was aimed to examine the effect of exposure to ELF EMF on one of the most stable learning named avoidance learning. It is a situation that animal not only does not receive reinforcement but also receives the stimuli which may threaten its survival. Since such irritating situations are generally serious threats, only once experimental effort makes a long remain stable learning. In this study, to measure memory, laboratory animals (mice) were evaluated with inhibitory (passive) avoidance task. An experimental method based on the measurement of step-down latency in passive avoidance learning has been developed for the study of memory in mice by Kameyama et al. (1986). This method, a state-dependent learning, has been known since 1930 (Overton, 1991), wherein the retrieval of newly acquired information is possible only if the subject is in the same sensory context and physiological state as during the encoding phase (Shulz et al., 2000).

Passive avoidance learning box is a wooden box with dimensions 30 × 30 × 40 cm and the floor of the 29 steel bars, the diameter of 0.3 cm. Bars are away from each other 1 cm. A wooden platform (4 × 4 × 4 cm) is placed in the middle floor of the box. An electric shock (1 Hz and 50 V, direct current (DC)) can control irritating situation (Grass S44-Quincy, Massachusetts, USA). In the learning stage, the animal was gently placed on the small wooden platform in the middle of box. Animal’s natural tendency to coming down from the platform make it to move in space of larger wooden box immediately. A 15-s electric shock was given as soon as the animal came down from the platform. So despite its natural tendency, animal learns to stay on platform. After 24 h and in test session, memory consolidation, measuring step-down latency (second) was calculated (Hiramatsu et al., 1995). The training and testing sessions were carried out between 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. in a light- and sound-attenuated room.

sec.title: The electromagnetic field exposure system
sec.p: EMF was applied in a room adjacent to that used for behavioral experiments. A sinusoidal magnetic field was created using a round-coil electromagnet made from a 1000-turned copper wire (0.50 mm). The electromagnet was supplied with a sinusoidal waveform signal generator (GFG-8019G, Good Will Instrument Co., Taiwan). Then the amplifier output droved to the coil, producing an ELF of 8 mT at the center of the coil. The desired intensity ELF (8 mT) was calibrated using Gauss meters (K72106-9-WALKER, USA) at the center of the coil. The heat generated by the coil dissipated due to the good ventilation in exposure area (see Figure 1). The electrical apparatuses and exposure system were adjusted on the laboratory nonmetallic table. Four hours after the learning session (first session) in the inhibitory avoidance learning apparatus, the experimental groups were exposed to EMF (in the center of round coil). Sham-control mice were placed in the same situation, but there was no electrical current and EMF.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Because of significant differences and innate ability in behavioral learning of animals, nonparametric statistical methods were used for data analysis. Using nonparametric methods is common in biopsychological research in which passive learning or other cognitive processes in mice are examined using an inhibitory avoidance apparatus (Rezayat et al., 2010; Ukai and Lin, 2002).

In the first step, using SPSS software differences in learning session between three groups in each sex were compared. By nonparametric method, the ranking in each group and mean ranking were calculated (see Figures 2 and 3).

caption.p: Mean ranks of step-down latency in learning session.
Mean ranks of step-down latency in learning session (memory consolidation).

sec.p: Moreover, using nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis test, the results showed that there was no significant difference between three male (Kruskal-Wallis test, χ2 = 0.268, df = 2, p < 0.875) and female (Kruskal-Wallis test, χ2 = 0.951, df = 2, p < 0.621) groups in the learning sessions. Compared with the sham-exposed male group and 4-h ELF exposure male group (10 mice in each group) in the learning session was not significant (sum of ranks: 109.0, 101.0; U Mann-Whitney = 46.00, p < 0.796). Similar result in comparison of sham-control female group and 4-h exposure group was obtained (sum of ranks: 116.50, 93.30; U Mann-Whitney = 38.50, p < 0.393).

The analysis of test session (memory consolidation) data showed that the step-down latency in experimental male group was significantly lower than the sham-exposed group (sum of rank in experimental group: 74, sum of rank in sham group: 136 and U Mann-Whitney = 19.00, p < 0.019) and in experimental female group, it was significantly lower than sham-exposed group too (sum of rank in experimental group: 71, sum of rank in sham group: 139 and U Mann-Whitney = 16.00, p < 0.009) (see Figure 4).

caption.p: Mean rank in step-down latency/latencies in experimental and sham groups.

sec.p: Also, there was no difference in sham groups and experimental groups in the general locomotor activity and impulsivity during the experiments observed by the researchers. Besides, the mice in sham group and in experimental group experienced the same physical space inside the coil.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: It is well known that the differences between step-down latency on the platform in learning and test sessions are an index of the rate of memory function in inhibitory (passive) avoidance task. Based on the results, it can be concluded that exposure to 8 mT, 50 Hz EMF impairs the memory consolidation. So animal’s memory will not be used and animal’s step-down latency and avoiding the shock reduces. Staying on the platform in the test session is considered an indication of memory permanence, which compared in the groups. In the sham control group, functions of mice showed that memory remained intact. In other words while mice in the control group and sham control group displayed intact memory functions, mice in experimental group, which were exposed to EMF stayed on platform for a shorter duration and showed dysfunctional memory operations. Therefore, it can be stated that exposure to EMF even in a 4-h exposure, can impair memory consolidation in mice. These findings are in agreement with Jadidi et al. (2007), Trimmel and Schweiger (1998), Lai (1996) and Lai and Carino (1999) about the impairing effects of ELF on cognitive functions.

Previous studies mainly focused on cognitive functions specially the memory and learning in different tasks and duration of exposure, so inconsistent results are predicted. Jadidi et al. (2007) provide evidence that exposure to a 50 Hz, 8 mT magnetic field for 20 min impaired consolidation spatial memory using a water maze but not the retrieval of learned information. Further, no effect was found in 2 mT magnetic field. McKay and Persinger (2000) also found 60 min exposure to 200–500 nT ELF before the training phase impaired spatial memory in the radial maze, whereas exposure before testing phase decreased the responding time of rats in this task. Lai et al. (1998) showed that the 60-min exposure to a 60 Hz, 1 mT ELF before training impaired the spatial memory in a water maze. Decreased perception, memory and cognition functions were found in a 60-min exposure to 50 Hz, 1 mT magnetic field in the human study (Trimmel and Schweiger, 1998). However, there are evidence which show no significant effects or a positive effect of ELF on learning and memory (Vázquez-García et al., 2004). For instance, Kurokawa et al. (2003) found no significant effects of a 50 Hz, 50 lT magnetic field on human brain. Also there was no harmful effects of 45-min exposure to a magnetic field at 0.75 mT on memory in mice (Sienkiewicz et al., 2001). This inconsistency may be due to the differences in protocols (such as type of task, intensity of the applied ELF, exposure duration, etc.) among different studies.

The mechanisms underlying the harmful effects of magnetic field on learning and memory are not known. The brain cholinergic system plays a crucial role in learning and memory (Whishaw, 1989; Whishaw and Tomie, 1987). It has been shown that exposure to ELF decreased the activities of cholinergic system in the frontal cortex and hippocampus, both regions are involved in memory processing (Lai and Carino, 1999). Thus, one possibility is that the impairment of cognition processing can result from decrement in transmission of cholinergic system. Manikonda, et al. (2007) contend that calcium ion could modify once exposing ELF; the modification of calcium ion and other factors such as GABA has been illustrated in different studies (Blackman, 2009). These changes and other possible impacts on electroencephalography (EEG) may explain the finding that brain and its cognitive operations could be affected by exposure to ELF.

In summary, findings indicate that 30-min and 90-min exposure to a 50 Hz 8 mT, EMFs can impair memory consolidation in a passive avoidance task. In agreement with others, our data indicates that exposure to ELF has an impairment effect on learning and memory functions. Therefore, further studies are required to find out the underlying mechanisms.

ack.p: We thank Dr Noor-Ali Farrokhi and Mr Hossein Moghtader-Nia for their useful ongoing expertise.
